title: Back in business: Get back to cycling in Europe
content:

Destination inspiration as you build up to your next European cycling holiday

As we head into the cooler winter months, it’s a good time to start dreaming of and planning ahead for your next cycling adventure abroad. If you’re an American Express® Cardmember, it’s also a good time to think about building up your Avios, the world-leading travel rewards currency, to make that trip more affordable and luxurious.

So, as international travel gets more feasible and everyone’s itching to get back on their bike abroad, read on for our top picks for your next cycling holiday in Europe – and to find out more about the Card that can help get you there.

Mallorca

If you’re keen to get away sooner rather than later, Mallorca is a great destination for some winter sun, with around 300 days of sunshine a year. Many famous climbs in the region offer a good but manageable challenge, with plenty of gorgeous landscapes and scenery to take in.

For example, the sharply winding Sa Calobra is one of the most beautiful rides in the world and arguably the hardest ride on the island – especially since you start with the descent down to the coast. And in this case, what goes down must come up!

If you visit in spring, you can take part in the Mallorca 312, which traverses 312km around the island and is on many a keen cyclist’s bucket list.

Flanders

Best known for the Spring Classics and for the challenges of the famous cobbled streets, you may want to plan your holiday for the quieter (and more predictable in terms of weather) summer months.

If you stay in the Oudenaarde area, you'll have easy access to the cobbled streets that make up part of the Tour de Flanders to test your technical skills, while also being surrounded by the culture and history of Belgium. There’s even the Tour of Flanders Museum in Oudenaarde, where you can learn all about the history of the sport in Flanders.

Girona

There’s a reason all the pros live in Girona. It has access to some of the most beautiful and diverse cycling routes in Europe and has a strong cycling culture – hosting some of the biggest cycling events and festivals on the continent, such as the Sea Otter Europe.

Highlights include the unbeatable range of dedicated cycling cafes, many of which are run by former pros including Rory Sutherland and Christian Meier, and the extensive network of greenways, historical roads, rural tracks to explore against the stunning Mediterranean scenery.

Top routes include the 353km Pirinexus cycle loop through the Spanish and French Pyrenees in the Catalan region, and the coastal route from Lloret-Tossa de Mar to Sant Feliu de Guíxols.

French Alps

Thanks to the Tour de France and Giro d’Italia, the French Alps have some of the most famous climbs in the world. They’re a great destination for any experienced cyclist who wants to see if they’ve got what it takes.

The climbs are challenging, the scenery is spectacular, and you’re in the land of wine and cheese so you can reward yourself after a hard day’s riding. With the Alps having big ski and cycling seasons, there are plenty of hotels and chalets to choose from which are set up for those travelling to enjoy outdoor activities.

Some of the top climbs include the Col de la Madeleine from Feissons-sur-Isère (length: 24.5km, altitude gain: 1,543m), one of the most challenging climbs in the French Alps and one of the most featured in the Tour de France, and the Col du Galibier from Valloire (length: 18.1km, altitude gain: 1,245m), which is another Tour de France favourite.


The Danube

If you’re looking for more of a holiday than a major cycling challenge, the road that runs along the Danube river is often listed as one of Europe’s most beautiful cycling routes. It’s a mostly flat, comfortable and gentle ride for the warm summer months, and therefore makes a great family holiday.

The river route runs 2,896km through several countries from the source in Germany, passing through Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia and Serbia all the way to the Black Sea in Romania – so there are lots of sections to choose from.

The Algarve

A great destination for road cyclists due to the year-round sunny weather (although it can get windy!) and abundance of great cycling roads, the Algarve offers a mixture of gentler coastal rides and more challenging rides up in the mountains. If you visit in February, you can catch your favourite riders in the Volta ao Algarve, one of the smaller professional races in the season.

One of the benefits of the Algarve for cycling is it’s not the most obvious destination, so you can enjoy a bit more peace and quiet than you might in the nearby Mediterranean islands. And perhaps one of the best things about choosing Portugal is that you can enjoy a delicious Pastel de Nata with your coffee when you stop for a break.

Planning for and enhancing your trip

You should have no problem finding travel agents and accommodation suited to keen cyclists in these destinations, but it’s also worth thinking outside of the box about how to make the most of your holiday.

For example, if you’re a small business owner planning your next trip, then the British Airways American Express® Accelerating Business Card offers a great opportunity. Cardmembers can use their routine business spend (be that on advertising, technology, office supplies, travel or utilities – to name just a few) to earn accelerated Avios, the world-leading travel rewards currency. Avios can be put towards a wide range of travel experiences such as reward flights, flight upgrades, hotel stays and car hire. It’s also worth checking and keeping up to date with travel guidance as you plan your trip, so you’re able to properly enjoy the well-earned riding break that you've planned.
